title: Can one paragraph constitute an essay? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say No. A well-structured essay normally starts off with an introductory paragraph, proceeds to work its way through a series of subsequent paragraphs, all of them developing an idea in logical form and order, and finally ends with a concluding paragraph which sums up everything said and deduces something from it. Each paragraph will normally begin with a topic sentence that outlines the main subject of that particular paragraph, then proceeds to develop it, before concluding with a link sentence. And that one will lead on to the subject of the next paragraph. By the time you have finished all these interlinking paragraphs, and reached your logical conclusion, the whole thing should be as fully connected as a string of beads. And the final paragraph, linking all the way back to the original introductory remarks, should fasten it all together like a well-strung and properly closed necklace. You could, if you really wanted to be difficult, dump all of these separate elements into one solid block of text, and invite your unfortunate reader to tackle it all in one go. But why would you want to be so unhelpful? I think paragraphing makes life a great deal easier, and your argument much clearer. Technically it is possible to write an essay in one paragraph, albeit maybe a long one. Realistically the quality of the essay will likely suffer. As a college professor, it is unlikely that I would accept a one paragraph essay since the minimum word count that I accept, for virtually any essay, is 350–700 words. Too many words for one paragraph. An essay consists of three parts. The opening or thesis which is a statement of what you are going to write about, then the body of the essay is the presentation of your facts or arguments which support your thesis, and then the conclusion which is a statement of what you wrote about. Better to use a minimum of three paragraphs.

No. If you write a proper paragraph, the scope is too narrow to be an essay. The demands of unity forbid a proper paragraph from comprising the entire arc of an argument demanded by a proper essay. By the same token, a proper essay, which introduces a topic, discusses it, and forms a conclusion, has a broad scope which cannot be contained in a single paragraph without violating the demands of scope and unity which apply to the paragraph. I could write a one paragraph story (microfiction) but not a one paragraph essay.

As far as I know it can’t. If you write just one paragraph, it can be a short story but not an essay. The most common essay pattern is a five-paragraph essay. If you don’t know how to write five paragraph essay, here’s its structure: introduction (it should include a hook and a thesis statement), the paragraph with your first argument, then your second and third argument, and, finally, conclusion that restates your thesis statement.

Short-answer essays are, generally, one paragraph. First sentence is generally the thesis statement, sentences 2- 10 are the evidence/analysis, and sentence last is the conclusion. Fit as many body sentences in there as you need and as the space allows.

I would say no. A single paragraph is a response, but not a whole essay in itself. You need to have a thesis and develop that thesis with examples. Even if you do write a long, three-page paragraph, this would be an organizational mess.

No. While the five-paragraph essay may be the most commonly known, the number of paragraphs an essay requires depends on the overall length and structure of the piece. The five-paragraph essay is formatted with a one-paragraph introduction, three-paragraph body and one-paragraph conclusion
